content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is an example of how you could solve this problem in Julia using DataFrames package.
```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4 or a4 quattro"
    df = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows
    df[:audi_a4_type] = fill(true, size(df)[1])
    
    return df
end
```
This function first filters the original DataFrame based on manufacturer and model. Then it adds a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values being true. Finally, it returns the modified DataFrame.
Please make sure to have the latest version of DataFrames package installed in your Julia environment before running this code. You can do that using the following command: 
```julia
using Pkg; Pkg.add("DataFrames")
```
